{{short description|Human-created solid waste in the sea or ocean}} {{redirect|Ocean dumping|shipping of waste across international borders|Environmental dumping}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} [[File:Marine debris on Hawaiian coast.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Marine debris on the [[Hawaii]]an coast]]
'''Marine debris''', also known as '''marine litter''', is human-created [[waste]] that has deliberately or accidentally been released in a [[lake]], [[sea]], [[ocean]], or [[waterway]]. Floating oceanic debris tends to accumulate at the center of [[gyre]]s and on [[coast]]lines,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/TECH/science/9807/28/toxic.seabirds/|title=Pollution invades small Pacific island|author=Gary Strieker|date=28 July 1998|accessdate=1 April 2008|publisher=CNN|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231062708/http://www.cnn.com/TECH/science/9807/28/toxic.seabirds/|archivedate=31 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> frequently washing aground, when it is known as ''beach litter'' or tidewrack. Deliberate disposal of wastes at sea is called ''ocean dumping''. Naturally occurring debris, such as [[driftwood]], are also present.
With the increasing use of [[plastic]], human influence has become an issue as many types of plastics do not [[Biodegradation|biodegrade]]. Waterborne plastic poses a serious threat to [[fish]], [[seabird]]s, [[marine reptile]]s, and [[marine mammal]]s, as well as to boats and coasts.<ref name="Facts22">{{cite web|url=http://marinedebris.noaa.gov/marinedebris101|title=Facts about marine debris|publisher=US NOAA|accessdate=10 April 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213110801/http://marinedebris.noaa.gov/marinedebris101/|archivedate=13 February 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Dumping, container spillages, litter washed into storm drains and waterways and wind-blown landfill waste all contribute to this problem.
In efforts to prevent and mediate marine debris and pollutants, laws and policies have been adopted internationally. Depending on relevance to the issues and various levels of contribution, some countries have introduced more specified protection policies.
==Types of debris== [[File:Beach at Msasani Bay, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.JPG|thumb|Debris on beach near [[Dar es Salaam]], Tanzania.]] [[File:Flostam tern island.JPG|thumb|Debris collected from beaches on Tern Island in the [[French Frigate Shoals]] over one month.]]
Researchers classify debris as either land- or ocean-based; in 1991, the [[United Nations]] Joint Group of Experts on the Scientific Aspects of Marine Pollution estimated that up to 80% of the pollution was land-based,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Sheavly | first1 = S. B. | last2 = Register | first2 = K. M. | title = Marine Debris & Plastics: Environmental Concerns, Sources, Impacts and Solutions | journal = Journal of Polymers and the Environment | volume = 15 | issue = 4 | pages = 301–305 | year = 2007 | doi = 10.1007/s10924-007-0074-3}}</ref> with the remaining 20% originating from catastrophic events or maritime sources.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Weiss | first1 = K.R. | title = The pileup of plastic debris is more than ugly ocean litter | journal = Knowable Magazine | year = 2017 | url = https://www.knowablemagazine.org/article/sustainability/2017/pileup-plastic-debris-more-ugly-ocean-litter | doi = 10.1146/knowable-120717-211902 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171209100516/https://www.knowablemagazine.org/article/sustainability/2017/pileup-plastic-debris-more-ugly-ocean-litter | archivedate = 9 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> More recent studies have found that more than half of plastic debris found on Korean shores is ocean-based.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jang|first=Yong Chang|last2=Lee |first2=Jongmyoung|last3=Hong |first3=Sunwook|last4=Lee |first4=Jong Su|last5=Shim|first5=Won Joon|last6=Song|first6=Young Kyoung|date=6 July 2014|title=Sources of plastic marine debris on beaches of Korea: More from the ocean than the land |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12601-014-0015-8 |journal=Ocean Science Journal|volume=49|issue=2|pages=151–162|doi=10.1007/s12601-014-0015-8|issn=1738-5261}}</ref>
A wide variety of man-made objects can become marine debris; [[plastic bag]]s, [[balloon]]s, [[buoy]]s, [[rope]], [[medical waste]], [[glass]] and [[plastic bottles]], cigarette stubs, [[Lighter|cigarette lighter]]s, [[beverage can]]s, [[polystyrene]], [[ghost net|lost fishing line and nets]], and various wastes from [[cruise ship pollution|cruise ships]] and [[Oil platform|oil rig]]s are among the items commonly found to have washed ashore. [[Six pack rings]], in particular, are considered emblematic of the problem.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.straightdope.com/classics/a990716.html |title=Should you cut up six-pack rings so they don't choke sea birds? |date=16 July 1999 |author=Cecil Adams |publisher=The Straight Dope |accessdate=11 August 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006061820/http://www.straightdope.com/classics/a990716.html |archivedate=6 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The US military used ocean dumping for unused weapons and bombs, including ordinary bombs, [[UXO]], landmines and chemical weapons from at least 1919 until 1970.<ref name=wbgh>{{cite news|author1=Edgar B. Herwick III|title=Explosive Beach Objects-- Just Another Example Of Massachusetts' Charm |url=http://wgbhnews.org/post/explosive-beach-objects-just-another-example-massachusetts-charm|accessdate=4 August 2015|work=WGBH news|publisher=PBS|date=29 July 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150803012411/http://wgbhnews.org/post/explosive-beach-objects-just-another-example-massachusetts-charm|archivedate=3 August 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Millions of pounds of [[Unexploded ordnance|ordnance]] were disposed of in the Gulf of Mexico and off the coasts of at least 16 states, from New Jersey to Hawaii (although these, of course, do not wash up onshore, and the US is not the only country who has practiced this).<ref name=me>{{cite news|title=Military Ordinance [sic] Dumped in Gulf of Mexico|url=http://www.maritime-executive.com/article/military-ordinance-dumped-in-gulf-of-mexico|accessdate=4 August 2015|work=Maritime Executive|date=3 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150807104225/http://maritime-executive.com/article/military-ordinance-dumped-in-gulf-of-mexico|archivedate=7 August 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Eighty percent of marine debris is plastic.<ref name=Weisman>{{cite book |author=Alan Weisman |title=The World Without Us |year=2007 |pages=112–128 |publisher=St. Martin's Thomas Dunne Books |isbn=0-312-34729-4 }}</ref> Plastics accumulate because they typically do not [[biodegradation|biodegrade]] as many other substances do. They [[photodegradation|photodegrade]] on exposure to sunlight, although they do so only under dry conditions, as [[water (molecule)|water]] inhibits [[photolysis]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.orionmagazine.org/index.php/articles/article/270/ |title=Polymers Are Forever |accessdate=1 July 2008 |date=Summer 2007 |author=Alan Weisman |publisher=Orion magazine |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516210457/http://www.orionmagazine.org/index.php/articles/article/270 |archivedate=16 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In a 2014 study using computer models, scientists from the group 5 Gyres, estimated 5.25 trillion pieces of plastic weighing 269,000 tons were dispersed in oceans in similar amount in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, and one-hundredth of them are particles the scale of a [[sand]].<ref>{{cite web|title=5 Trillion Pieces of Ocean Trash Found, But Fewer Particles Than Expected|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/12/141211-ocean-plastics-garbage-patches-5-gyres-pollution-environment/|accessdate=25 January 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205025927/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/12/141211-ocean-plastics-garbage-patches-5-gyres-pollution-environment/|archivedate=5 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Ghost nets=== {{Main|Ghost net}} [[File:Turtle entangled in marine debris (ghost net).jpg|thumb|A [[green turtle|turtle]] trapped in a [[ghost net]], an abandoned fishing net]] [[Fishing net]]s left or lost in the ocean by fishermen – [[ghost net]]s – can [[Plastic pollution#Entanglement|entangle]] [[fish]], [[dolphin]]s, [[sea turtle]]s, [[shark]]s, [[dugong]]s, [[crocodile]]s, [[seabird]]s, [[crab]]s, and other creatures. These nets restrict movement, causing starvation, laceration and infection, and, in animals that breathe air, suffocation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/highlands_and_islands/6248366.stm |title='Ghost fishing' killing seabirds |accessdate=1 April 2008 |date=28 June 2007 |publisher=BBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105012108/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/highlands_and_islands/6248366.stm |archivedate=5 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Plastic=== {{Main|Plastic pollution}}
8.8 million metric tons of plastic waste are dumped in the world's oceans each year. Asia was the leading source of mismanaged plastic waste, with China alone accounting for 2.4 million metric tons.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Macrae|first1=Fiona|title=Eight million tons of plastic is dumped at sea each year.|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2951256/Study-World-dumps-8-8-million-tons-plastics-oceans.html|newspaper=Daily Mail|accessdate=21 February 2015|date=12 February 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150221023552/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2951256/Study-World-dumps-8-8-million-tons-plastics-oceans.html|archivedate=21 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |title=Asia Leads World in Dumping Plastic in Seas |author=Robert Lee Hotz |date=13 February 2015 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB20530567965804683707904580457713291864670 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223140548/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB20530567965804683707904580457713291864670 |archivedate=23 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Plastic waste has reached all the world's oceans. This [[plastic pollution#Effects on animals|plastic pollution]] harms an estimated 100,000 [[sea turtle]]s and marine mammals and 1,000,000 sea creatures each year.<ref name="STRP Ban Plastic Bags">{{cite web|url=http://www.seaturtles.org/article.php?id=1751 |title=A Ban on Plastic Bags Will Save the Lives of California's Endangered Leatherback Sea Turtles |year=2010 |publisher=Sea Turtle Restoration Project |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128000648/http://seaturtles.org/article.php?id=1751 |archivedate=28 November 2010 |df= }}</ref> Larger plastics (called "macroplastics") such as [[plastic shopping bag]]s can clog the digestive tracts of larger animals when consumed by them<ref name=UNEP>{{cite web |url=http://www.unep.org/regionalseas/marinelitter/publications/docs/anl_oview.pdf |format=PDF |title=Marine Litter: An analytical overview |accessdate=1 August 2008 |year=2005 |publisher=United Nations Environment Programme |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20070717141400/http://www.unep.org/regionalseas/marinelitter/publications/docs/anl_oview.pdf |archivedate=17 July 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and can cause starvation through restricting the movement of food, or by filling the stomach and tricking the animal into thinking it is full. [[Microplastics]] on the other hand harm smaller marine life. For example, [[pelagic]] plastic pieces in the center of our ocean’s gyres outnumber live marine plankton, and are passed up the food chain to reach all marine life.<ref name="Moore et al, 2007">C.J. Moore et al., 2001. A Comparison of Plastic and Plankton in the North Pacific Central Gyre. Marine Pollution Bulletin 42(12): 1297‐1300</ref> A 1994 study of the [[seabed]] using [[trawl net]]s in the North-Western [[Mediterranean]] around the coasts of Spain, France, and Italy reported mean concentrations of debris of 1,935 items per square kilometre. Plastic debris accounted for 77%, of which 93% was plastic bags.<ref name=UNEP />
====Nurdles==== {{Main|Plastic particle water pollution}}
[[File:Nurdles 01 gentlemanrook.jpg|thumb|A handful of [[Microplastics|nurdle]]s, spilled from a train in [[Pineville, Louisiana|Pineville]], [[Louisiana]]]] [[Plastic particle water pollution|Nurdle]]s, also known as "mermaids' tears", are plastic pellets, typically under five millimetres in diameter, that are a major component of marine debris. They are a raw material in plastics manufacturing, and enter the [[natural environment]] when spilled. [[physical weathering|Weathering]] produces ever smaller pieces. Nurdles strongly resemble [[fish eggs]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/6218698.stm |title=Plastics 'poisoning world's seas' |accessdate=1 April 2008 |date=7 December 2006 |publisher=BBC News |first=Maggie |last=Ayre |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224090306/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/6218698.stm |archivedate=24 December 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Deep-sea debris=== Litter, made from diverse materials that are denser than surface water (such as [[glass]]es, metals and some plastics), have been found to spread over the floor of seas and open oceans, where it can become entangled in [[coral]]s and interfere with other [[Benthos|sea-floor life]], or even become buried under sediment, making [[Marine salvage|clean-up]] extremely difficult, especially due to the wide area of its dispersal compared to [[shipwrecks]]. Research performed by [[MBARI]] found items including plastic bags [[Bathyal zone|below 2000m depth]] off the west coast of North America and around Hawaii.<ref name="MBARI News Release">{{cite web |url=http://www.mbari.org/news/news_releases/2013/deep-debris/deep-debris-release.html |title=MBARI News Release: MBARI research shows where trash accumulates in the deep sea |year=2013 |publisher=Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute |accessdate=7 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707055536/http://www.mbari.org/news/news_releases/2013/deep-debris/deep-debris-release.html |archivedate=7 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Sources of debris== [[File:Friendly Floatees.png|thumb|upright=1.5|The travel of the [[Friendly Floatees]].]]
An estimated 10,000 [[Containerization|containers]] at sea each year are lost by [[container ship]]s, usually during storms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2001/06/0619_seacargo.html |title=Lost Sea Cargo: Beach Bounty or Junk? |accessdate=8 April 2008 |date=19 June 2001 |author=Janice Podsada |publisher=National Geographic News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080406043240/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2001/06/0619_seacargo.html |archivedate=6 April 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> One spillage occurred in the [[Pacific Ocean]] in 1992, when thousands of [[Friendly Floatees|rubber ducks and other toys]] (now known as the "Friendly Floatees") went overboard during a storm. The toys have since been found all over the world, providing a better understanding of [[ocean current]]s. Similar incidents have happened before, such as when ''[[Hansa Carrier]]'' dropped 21 containers (with one notably containing buoyant [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] shoes).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/TECH/science/05/28/coolsc.oceansecrets/index.html |title=How sneakers, toys and hockey gear help ocean science |accessdate=8 April 2008 |date=28 May 2003 |author=Marsha Walton |publisher=CNN |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408065423/http://www.cnn.com/2003/TECH/science/05/28/coolsc.oceansecrets/index.html |archivedate=8 April 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2007, [[MSC Napoli]] beached in the [[English Channel]], dropping hundreds of containers, most of which washed up on the [[Jurassic Coast]], a [[World Heritage Site]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/devon/6287457.stm |title=Scavengers take washed-up goods |accessdate=8 April 2008 |date=22 January 2007 |publisher=BBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209141945/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/devon/6287457.stm |archivedate=9 February 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In Halifax Harbour, Nova Scotia, 52% of items were generated by recreational use of an urban park, 14% from sewage disposal and only 7% from shipping and fishing activities.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Walker | first1 = T.R. | last2 = Grant | first2 = J. | last3 = Archambault | first3 = M-C. | year = 2006 | title = Accumulation of marine debris on an intertidal beach in an urban park (Halifax Harbour, Nova Scotia) | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233420832_Accumulation_of_marine_debris_on_an_intertidal_beach_in_an_urban/file/79e4150a7c934a54d1.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Water Quality Research Journal of Canada | volume = 41 | issue = 3| pages = 256–262 }}</ref> Around four fifths<ref name=Algalita>{{cite web |url=http://www.algalita.org/pdf/PLASTIC%20DEBRIS%20ENGLISH.pdf |title=Plastic Debris: from Rivers to Sea |accessdate=29 May 2008 |publisher=Algalita Marine Research Foundation |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819214304/http://www.algalita.org/pdf/PLASTIC%20DEBRIS%20ENGLISH.pdf |archivedate=19 August 2008 |df= }}</ref> of oceanic debris is from rubbish blown onto the water from [[landfill]]s, and [[urban runoff]].<ref name="Facts22"/>
Some studies show that marine debris may be dominant in particular locations. For example, a 2016 study of Aruba found that debris found the windward side of the island was predominantly marine debris from distant sources.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Scisciolo| first1 = Tobia | year = 2016 | title = Beach debris on Aruba, Southern Caribbean: Attribution to local land-based and distal marine-based sources | url = https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X16301679 | journal = Marine Pollution Bulletin | volume = 106| issue = -2| pages = 49-57 }}</ref> In 2013, debris from six beaches in Korea was collected and analyzed: 56% was found to be "ocean-based" and 44% "land-based".<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Yong| first1 = C | year = 2013 | title = Sources of plastic marine debris on beaches of Korea: More from the ocean than the land | url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12601-014-0015-8 | journal = Ocean Science Journal | volume = 49| issue = 2| pages = 151-162 }}</ref>
In the 1987 [[Syringe Tide]], medical waste washed ashore in [[New Jersey]] after having been blown from [[Fresh Kills Landfill]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEFD81439F93BA35751C1A961948260 |title=New York City to Pay Jersey Town $1 Million Over Shore Pollution |accessdate=25 June 2008 |date=8 December 1987 |author=Alfonso Narvaez |publisher=The New York Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090311010114/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEFD81439F93BA35751C1A961948260 |archivedate=11 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://library.marist.edu/diglib/EnvSci/archives/hudsmgmt/ny-njharborestuaryprogram/debris.html |title=A Summary of the Proposed Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan |accessdate=25 June 2008 |date=February 1995 |publisher=New York-New Jersey Harbor Estuary Program |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050524210352/http://library.marist.edu/diglib/EnvSci/archives/hudsmgmt/ny-njharborestuaryprogram/debris.html |archivedate=24 May 2005 |df= }}</ref> On the remote sub-Antarctic island of [[South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands|South Georgia]], fishing-related debris, approximately 80% plastics, are responsible for the entanglement of large numbers of [[Antarctic fur seal]]s.<ref>{{Citation |last=Walker |first=T. R. |last2=Reid |first2=K. |last3=Arnould |first3=J. P. Y. |last4=Croxall |first4=J. P. |year=1997 |title=Marine debris surveys at Bird Island, South Georgia 1990–1995 |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=34 |issue=1 |pages=61–65 |doi=10.1016/S0025-326X(96)00053-7 }}.</ref>
Marine litter is even found on the floor of the Arctic ocean.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57540392/plastic-trash-invades-arctic-seafloor|title=Plastic trash invades arctic seafloor|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025213953/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57540392/plastic-trash-invades-arctic-seafloor/|archivedate=25 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Great Pacific Garbage Patch== {{main|Great Pacific garbage patch|l1=Great Pacific Garbage Patch}}
[[File:North Pacific Subtropical Convergence Zone.jpg|thumb|right|The currents of the North Pacific Gyre spiral inwards, depositing debris in the convergence zone.]] Once waterborne, debris becomes mobile. Flotsam can be blown by the wind, or follow the flow of [[ocean current]]s, often ending up in the middle of [[oceanic gyre]]s where currents are weakest. The [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]] is one such example of this, comprising a vast region of the North [[Pacific Ocean]] rich with anthropogenic wastes. Estimated to be double the size of [[Texas]], the area contains more than 3 million tons of plastic.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/1011/p02s01-usgn.html |title=Congress acts to clean up the ocean - A garbage patch in the Pacific is at least triple the size of Texas, but some estimates put it larger than the continental United States |accessdate=10 October 2008 |publisher=''The Christian Science Monitor'' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005231145/http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/1011/p02s01-usgn.html |archivedate=5 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Pacific-garbage-patch-map 2010 noaamdp.jpg|thumb|left|Pacific ocean currents have created 3 "islands" of debris.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://marinedebris.noaa.gov/movement/great-pacific-garbage-patch |title=Great Pacific Garbage Patch |website= Marine Debris Division – Office of Response and Restoration |publisher=NOAA |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140417124654/https://marinedebris.noaa.gov/movement/great-pacific-garbage-patch |archivedate=17 April 2014 |accessdate=30 November 2018 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>]] Patches may be large enough to be viewed by [[satellite]]. For example, when the Malaysian Flight [[MH370]], disappeared in 2014, satellites were scanning the oceans surface for any sign of it, and instead of finding debris from the plane they came across floating garbage.<ref name=":0">Parker, Laura. "With Millions of Tons of Plastic in Oceans, More Scientists Studying Impact." ''National Geographic''. National Geographic Society, 13 June 2014. Web. 3 April 2016. </ref> The gyre contains approximately six pounds of plastic for every pound of [[plankton]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mindfully.org/Plastic/Ocean/Pacific-Garbage-Patch27oct02.htm |title=Great Pacific garbage patch: Plastic turning vast area of ocean into ecological nightmare |accessdate=13 October 2008 |publisher=''Santa Barbara News-Press'' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912023857/http://www.mindfully.org/Plastic/Ocean/Pacific-Garbage-Patch27oct02.htm |archivedate=12 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The oceans may contain as much as one hundred million [[ton]]s of plastic.<ref name=Algalita/> It is estimated that each garbage patch in the ocean have up to one million tons of trash swirling around in them, sometimes extending down to around one hundred feet below the surface.<ref>Matsumura, Satsuki, and Keiichi Nasu. "Distribution of Floating Debris in the North Pacific Ocean: Sighting Surveys 1986–1991." ''Springer Series on Environmental Management Marine Debris'' (1997): 15-24. ''Marine Debris Found in the North Pacific''. EPA, Nov. 2011. Web. 3 April 2016. </ref> Some items that have been extracted from these garbage patches are: a drum of hazardous chemicals, plastic hangers, tires, cable cords, a ton of tangled netting etc.
Over 40% of oceans are classified as subtropical gyres, a fourth of the planets surface area has become an accumulator of floating plastic debris.
[[Island]]s situated within gyres frequently have coastlines flooded by waste that washes ashore; prime examples are [[Midway Atoll|Midway]]<ref name=midway>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/7314240.stm |title=New 'battle of Midway' over plastic |accessdate=1 April 2008 |date=26 March 2008 |publisher=BBC News |first=David |last=Shukman |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080330232243/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/7314240.stm |archivedate=30 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and [[Hawaii]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/6740161.stm |title=Plastic blights Hawaii's beaches |accessdate=1 April 2008 |date=11 June 2007 |publisher=BBC News |first=Matt |last=Wells |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080331023304/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/6740161.stm |archivedate=31 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Clean-up teams around the world patrol beaches to attack this environmental threat.<ref name=midway />
More than 37 million pieces of plastic debris have accumulated on [[Henderson Island (Pitcairn Islands)|Henderson Island]], a remote [[Pitcairn island]] in the South Pacific, reported to be the highest density of debris reported anywhere in the world, yet the trash accounts for only 1.98 seconds’ worth of the annual global production of plastic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/15/528470657/millions-of-pieces-of-plastic-are-piling-up-on-otherwise-pristine-pacific-island|title=Millions Of Pieces Of Plastic Are Piling Up On An Otherwise Pristine Pacific Island|author=|date=|website=npr.org|accessdate=1 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180128182528/https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/15/528470657/millions-of-pieces-of-plastic-are-piling-up-on-otherwise-pristine-pacific-island|archivedate=28 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Environmental impact== [[File:Albatross at Midway Atoll Refuge (8080507529).jpg|thumb|The remains of an [[Laysan albatross|albatross]] containing ingested flotsam.]]
Many animals that live on or in the sea [[feeding|consume]] flotsam by mistake, as it often looks similar to their natural prey.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/archives/7135 |title=Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas |accessdate=1 April 2008 |date=2 August 2006 |author=Kenneth R. Weiss |publisher=Los Angeles Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080923134138/http://www.pulitzer.org/archives/7135 |archivedate=23 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Bulky plastic debris may become permanently lodged in the digestive tracts of these animals, blocking the passage of food and causing death through starvation or infection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naturalhistorymag.com/features/172720/trash-revisited |title=Across the Pacific Ocean, plastics, plastics, everywhere. |accessdate=12 July 2016 |date=November 2003 |author=Charles Moore |publisher=Natural History |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425205435/http://www.naturalhistorymag.com/features/172720/trash-revisited |archivedate=25 April 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Tiny floating plastic particles also resemble [[zooplankton]], which can lead [[filter feeder]]s to consume them and cause them to enter the ocean [[food chain]]. In samples taken from the [[North Pacific Gyre]] in 1999 by the Algalita Marine Research Foundation, the mass of plastic exceeded that of zooplankton by a factor of six.<ref name=Weisman/><ref name=AlgalitaVid>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rVwuPSLx2Xc |title=Plastics and Marine Debris |accessdate=1 July 2008 |year=2006 |publisher=Algalita Marine Research Foundation |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714181845/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rVwuPSLx2Xc |archivedate=14 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Toxic additives used in plastic manufacturing can [[wikt:leach|leach]] into their surroundings when exposed to water. Waterborne [[hydrophobic]] pollutants [[adsorption|collect and magnify on the surface]] of plastic debris,<ref name=Algalita /> thus making plastic more deadly in the ocean than it would be on land.<ref name=Weisman /> Hydrophobic contaminants [[bioaccumulation|bioaccumulate]] in fatty tissues, [[biomagnification|biomagnifying]] up the food chain and pressuring [[apex predator]]s and humans.<ref name=Engler>{{cite journal|last=Engler|first=Richard E.|title=The Complex Interaction between Marine Debris and Toxic Chemicals in the Ocean|journal=Environmental Science & Technology|date=20 November 2012|volume=46|issue=22|pages=12302–12315|doi=10.1021/es3027105}}</ref> Some plastic additives disrupt the [[endocrine system]] when consumed; others can suppress the [[immune system]] or decrease reproductive rates.<ref name=AlgalitaVid />
The hydrophobic nature of plastic surfaces stimulates rapid formation of [[biofilm]]s,<ref name="Reisser"/> which support a wide range of metabolic activities, and drive succession of other micro- and macro-organisms.<ref>{{Citation | last1=Davet| first1=ME |last2=O'Toole |first2=GA |year=2000 |title=Microbial biofilms: from ecology to molecular genetics |journal=Microbiol Mol Bio R|volume=64 | issue=4 |pages=847–867 |pmc=99016 |pmid=11104821 |doi=10.1128/MMBR.64.4.847-867.2000}}</ref>
Concern among experts has grown since the 2000s that some organisms have [[Adaptation|adapted]] to live on<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2007/04/070423-ocean-plastic.html |title=Ocean Debris: Habitat for Some, Havoc for Environment, |accessdate=1 August 2008 |date=23 April 2007 |publisher=National Geographic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807063745/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2007/04/070423-ocean-plastic.html |archivedate=7 August 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> floating plastic debris, allowing them to disperse with ocean currents and thus potentially become [[invasive species]] in distant ecosystems.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/1948714.stm |title=Rubbish menaces Antarctic species |accessdate=1 August 2008 |date=24 April 2002 |publisher=BBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228183446/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/1948714.stm |archivedate=28 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Research in 2014 in the waters around Australia<ref name=Reisser>{{Cite journal|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0100289 |title=Millimeter-Sized Marine Plastics: A New Pelagic Habitat for Microorganisms and Invertebrates |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=9 |issue=6 |pages=e100289 |accessdate=26 January 2015 |date=18 June 2014 |publisher=''PLoS ONE'' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929101517/http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0100289 |archivedate=29 September 2015 |df=dmy-all |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0100289 |pmid=24941218 |last1=Reisser |first1=Julia |last2=Shaw |first2=Jeremy |last3=Hallegraeff |first3=Gustaaf |last4=Proietti |first4=Maira |last5=Barnes |first5=David K. A |last6=Thums |first6=Michele |last7=Wilcox |first7=Chris |last8=Hardesty |first8=Britta Denise |last9=Pattiaratchi |first9=Charitha }}</ref> confirmed a wealth of such colonists, even on tiny flakes, and also found thriving ocean bacteria eating into the plastic to form pits and grooves. These researchers showed that "plastic biodegradation is occurring at the sea surface" through the action of bacteria, and noted that this is congruent with a new body of research on such bacteria. Their finding is also congruent with the other major research undertaken<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/12/141218-deep-ocean-micro-plastic-fibers-trash-discovery/ |title=Where Has All the (Sea Trash) Plastic Gone? |accessdate=26 January 2015 |date=18 December 2014 |publisher=National Geographic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204035854/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/12/141218-deep-ocean-micro-plastic-fibers-trash-discovery/ |archivedate=4 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> in 2014, which sought to answer the riddle of the overall lack of build up of floating plastic in the oceans, despite ongoing high levels of dumping. Plastics were found as microfibres in core samples drilled from sediments at the bottom of the deep ocean. The cause of such widespread deep sea deposition has yet to be determined.
Not all [[Human impact on the environment|anthropogenic]] artifacts placed in the oceans are harmful. Iron and concrete structures typically do little damage to the environment because they generally sink to the bottom and become immobile, and at shallow depths they can even provide scaffolding for [[artificial reef]]s. Ships and subway cars have been deliberately sunk for that purpose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://192.5.14.110/pubs/monograph_reports/MR1377/MR1377.ch5.pdf |work=Disposal Options for Ships |title=Chapter 5: Reefing |accessdate=3 May 2008 |date=2 August 2006 |author1=Ron Hess |author2=Denis Rushworth |author3=Michael Hynes |author4=John Peters |publisher=Rand Corporation |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629110318/http://192.5.14.110/pubs/monograph_reports/MR1377/MR1377.ch5.pdf |archivedate=29 June 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Additionally, [[hermit crab]]s have been known to use pieces of beach litter as a shell when they cannot find an actual seashell of the size they need.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Miller|first1=Shawn|title=Crabs With Beach Trash Homes – Okinawa, Japan|url=http://okinawanaturephotography.com/crabs-with-beach-trash-homes-okinawa-japan/|website=Okinawa Nature Photography|accessdate=14 October 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171014084009/http://okinawanaturephotography.com/crabs-with-beach-trash-homes-okinawa-japan/|archivedate=14 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Debris removal== [[File:DC WASA Marine Debris Skimmer.jpg|thumb|Skimmer boat used to remove floating debris and trash from the [[Potomac River|Potomac]] and [[Anacostia River|Anacostia]] rivers]]
Techniques for collecting and removing marine (or riverine) debris include the use of debris skimmer boats ''(pictured)''. Devices such as these can be used where floating debris presents a danger to navigation. For example, the [[US Army Corps of Engineers]] removes 90 tons of "drifting material" from [[San Francisco Bay]] every month. The Corps has been doing this work since 1942, when a [[seaplane]] carrying Admiral [[Chester W. Nimitz]] collided with a piece of floating debris and sank, costing the life of its pilot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spn.usace.army.mil/newsrelease/newsrelease_11_07_07.html |title=Debris collection onsite after Bay Bridge struck |publisher=US Army Corps of Engineers |accessdate=7 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109084709/http://www.spn.usace.army.mil/newsrelease/newsrelease_11_07_07.html |archivedate=9 January 2009 |df= }}</ref> Once debris becomes "beach litter", collection by hand and specialized [[beach cleaner|beach-cleaning machines]] are used to gather the debris.
Elsewhere, "trash traps" are installed on small rivers to capture waterborne debris before it reaches the sea. For example, [[South Australia]]'s [[Adelaide]] operates a number of such traps, known as "trash racks" or "gross pollutant traps" on the [[Torrens River]], which flows (during the wet season) into [[Gulf St Vincent]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amlrnrm.sa.gov.au/ProjectsTaskforce/TrashRacks/tabid/544/Default.aspx|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719020149/http://www.amlrnrm.sa.gov.au/ProjectsTaskforce/TrashRacks/tabid/544/Default.aspx|dead-url=yes|archivedate=19 July 2008|title=Trash Racks|publisher=Adelaide and Mount Lofty Ranges Natural Resources Management Board|accessdate=7 February 2009}}</ref>
In lakes or near the coast, manual removal can also be used. [[Project AWARE]] for example promotes the idea of letting dive clubs clean up litter, for example as a diving exercise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectaware.org/project/10Tips|title=10 Tips for Divers to Protect the Ocean Planet|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923111851/http://www.projectaware.org/project/10Tips|archivedate=23 September 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On the sea, the removal of artificial debris (i.e. plastics) is still in its infancy. However some projects have been started which used ships with nets (Kaisei and New Horizon) to catch some plastics, primarily for research purposes. Another method to gather artificial litter has been proposed by [[Boyan Slat]]. He suggested using platforms with arms to gather the debris, situated inside the current of gyres.<ref>{{cite web |website=MarineDebris.Info |url=http://marinedebris.info/wiki/great-pacific-garbage-patch |title=Methods for collecting plastic litter at sea |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024154340/http://marinedebris.info/wiki/great-pacific-garbage-patch |archive-date=24 October 2013 }}</ref>
Another issue is that removing marine debris from our oceans can potentially cause more harm than good. Cleaning up micro-plastics could also accidentally take out plankton, which are the main lower level food group for the marine food chain and over half of the photosynthesis on earth.<ref name=":0" /> One of the most efficient and cost effective ways to help reduce the amount of plastic entering our oceans is to not participate in using single use plastics, avoid plastic bottled drinks such as water bottles, use reusable shopping bags, and to buy products with reusable packaging.<ref>Wabnitz, C., & Nichols, W. J. (2010). Editorial: Plastic pollution: An ocean emergency. ''Marine Turtle Newsletter,'' (129), 1-4.</ref>
Once a year there is a diving marine debris removal operation in [[Scapa Flow]] in the [[Orkney]]s, run by [http://www.ghostfishing.org/ Ghost Fishing UK], funded by [[World Animal Protection]] and [https://www.fatfacefoundation.org/ Fat Face Foundation].<ref>''[[Daily Telegraph]] 28 September 2017, page 31</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.orcadian.co.uk/lost-fishing-gear-recovered-scapa-flow/|title=Lost fishing gear being recovered from Scapa Flow - The Orcadian Online|author=|date=25 September 2017|website=orcadian.co.uk|accessdate=1 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171211071923/https://www.orcadian.co.uk/lost-fishing-gear-recovered-scapa-flow/|archivedate=11 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://divemagazine.co.uk/eco/7783-ghost-fishing-to-be-charged-for-cleanups|title=GHOST FISHING UK TO BE CHARGED FOR CLEANUPS|first=|last=Crowley|date=|website=divemagazine.co.uk|accessdate=1 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929044334/http://divemagazine.co.uk/eco/7783-ghost-fishing-to-be-charged-for-cleanups|archivedate=29 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Laws and treaties == The ocean is a [[Global commons|global common]], so negative [[Externality|externalities]] of marine debris are not usually experienced by the producer. In the 1950s, the importance of government intervention with marine pollution protocol was recognized at the First Conference on the Law of the Sea.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal|last=Leous|first=Justin P.|last2=Parry|first2=Neal B.|date=2005|title=WHO IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MARINE DEBRIS? THE INTERNATIONAL POLITICS OF CLEANING OUR OCEANS|journal=Journal of International Affairs|volume=59|issue=1|pages=257–269|doi=10.2307/24358243|jstor=24358243|doi-broken-date=2018-05-27}}</ref>
Ocean dumping is controlled by [[international law]], including: * [[Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter|The London Convention]] (1972) – a [[United Nations]] agreement to control ocean dumping<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/owow/ocpd/icnetbri.html|title=London Convention|publisher=US EPA|accessdate=29 May 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309032139/http://www.epa.gov/owow/ocpd/icnetbri.html|archivedate=9 March 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter consisted of twenty two articles addressing expectations of contracting parties.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|date=1973|title=Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter|journal=The American Journal of International Law|volume=67|issue=3|pages=626–636|doi=10.2307/2199200|jstor=2199200}}</ref> The three annexes defined many compounds, substances, and materials that are unacceptable to deposit into the ocean.<ref name=":12" /> Examples of such matter include: [[Mercury (element)|mercury compounds]], [[lead]], [[cyanide]]s, and [[radioactive waste]]s.<ref name=":12" /> * [[MARPOL 73/78]] – a convention designed to minimize pollution of the seas, including dumping, oil and exhaust pollution<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imo.org/en/About/Conventions/ListOfConventions/Pages/International-Convention-for-the-Prevention-of-Pollution-from-Ships-(MARPOL).aspx|title=International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL)|website=www.imo.org|accessdate=23 July 2015}}</ref> The original MARPOL convention did not consider dumping from ships, but was revised in 1978 to include restrictions on marine vessels.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tharpes|first=Yvonne L.|date=1989|title=International Environmental Law: Turning the Tide on Marine Pollution|journal=The University of Miami Inter-American Law Review|volume=20|issue=3|pages=579–614|doi=10.2307/40176192|jstor=40176192|doi-broken-date=2018-05-27}}</ref> * [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|UNCLOS]]- signed in 1982, but effective in 1994, United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea emphasized the importance of protecting the entire ocean and not only specified coastal regions.<ref name=":03" /> UNCLOS enforced restrictions on pollution, including a stress on land-based sources.<ref name=":03" /> Regulations imposed by this agreement have potential to help mediate effects of [[climate change]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Redgwell|first=Catherine|date=2012|title=UNCLOS and Climate Change|jstor=10.5305/procannmeetasil.106.0406|journal=Proceedings of the Annual Meeting (American Society of International Law)|volume=106|pages=406–409|doi=10.5305/procannmeetasil.106.0406}}</ref>
===Australian law=== One of the earliest anti-dumping laws was Australia's ''Beaches, Fishing Grounds and Sea Routes Protection Act 1932'', which prohibited the discharge of "garbage, rubbish, ashes or organic refuse" from "any vessel in Australian waters" without prior written permission from the federal government. It also required permission for [[scuttling]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C1932A00073 |publisher=Federal Register of Legislation|title=Beaches, Fishing Grounds and Sea Routes Protection Act 1932}}</ref> The act was passed in response to large amounts of garbage washing up on the beaches of [[Sydney]] and [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] from vessels outside the reach of [[Local government in Australia|local governments]] and the [[New South Wales]] government.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U--LBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA230 |title=Sydney Beaches: A History |author=Caroline Ford |page=230 |year=2014 |publisher=NewSouth}}</ref> It was repealed and replaced by the ''Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981'', which gave effect to the London Convention.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2016C00778 |publisher=Federal Register of Legislation |title=Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981}}</ref>
===European law=== In 1972 and 1974, conventions were held in [[Oslo]] and [[Paris]] respectively, and resulted in the passing of the [[Convention for the Protection of the Marine Environment of the North-East Atlantic|OSPAR Convention]], an international treaty controlling marine pollution in the north-east [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ospar.org/eng/html/welcome.html|title=The OSPAR Convention|publisher=OSPAR Commission|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212075312/http://www.ospar.org/eng/html/welcome.html|archivedate=12 February 2008|deadurl=yes|accessdate=29 May 2008|df=}}</ref> The [[Barcelona Convention]] protects the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. The [[Water Framework Directive]] of 2000 is a [[Directive (European Union)|European Union directive]] committing [[Member State of the European Union|EU member states]] to free inland and coastal waters from human influence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32000L0060:EN:HTML|title=Directive 2000/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy|publisher=EurLex|accessdate=29 May 2008}}</ref> In the United Kingdom, the [[Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009]] is designed to "ensure clean healthy, safe, productive and biologically diverse oceans and seas, by putting in place better systems for delivering sustainable development of marine and coastal environment".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/marine/legislation/mcaa/index.htm|title=Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009|publisher=UK Defra|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402220928/http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/marine/legislation/mcaa/index.htm|archivedate=2 April 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=29 July 2008|df=}}</ref>
===United States law=== [[File:No_Dumping_Drains_to_Stream_by_David_Shankbone.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:No_Dumping_Drains_to_Stream_by_David_Shankbone.jpg|thumb|A sign above a sewer in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]] warning people to not pollute the local stream by [[Environmental dumping|dumping]]. Eighty percent of marine debris reaches the sea via rivers.]] In the waters of the United States, there have been many observed consequences of pollution including: [[Dead zone (ecology)|hypoxic zones]], harmful agal blooms, and threatened species.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Craig |first=R. |date=2005 |title=Protecting International Marine Biodiversity: International Treaties and National Systems of Marine Protected Areas |journal=Journal of Land Use & Environmental Law |volume=20 |issue=2 |pages=333-369 |jstor=42842976 }}</ref> In 1972, the [[United States Congress]] passed the [[Ocean Dumping Act]], giving the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] power to monitor and regulate the dumping of sewage sludge, industrial waste, radioactive waste and biohazardous materials into the nation's territorial waters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://epw.senate.gov/mprsa72.pdf|title=Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972|date=29 December 2000|publisher=US Senate |format=PDF |accessdate=29 May 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530014214/http://epw.senate.gov/mprsa72.pdf |archivedate=30 May 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Act was amended sixteen years later to include [[medical waste]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/history/topics/mprsa/02.htm |title=Ocean Dumping Ban Act of 1988 |date=21 November 1988 |publisher=US EPA |accessdate=29 May 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511183756/http://www.epa.gov/history/topics/mprsa/02.htm |archivedate=11 May 2009 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> It is illegal to dispose of any plastic in US waters.<ref name="Facts22"/>
===Ownership=== [[Property law]], [[admiralty law]] and the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|law of the sea]] may be of relevance when [[lost, mislaid, and abandoned property]] is found at sea. [[Marine salvage|Salvage law]] rewards salvors for risking life and property to rescue the property of another from peril. On land the distinction between deliberate and accidental loss led to the concept of a "[[treasure trove]]". In the [[United Kingdom]], shipwrecked goods should be reported to a [[Receiver of Wreck]], and if identifiable, they should be returned to their rightful owner.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6287047.stm |title=Can you keep ship-wrecked goods? |accessdate=29 May 2008 |date=22 January 2007 |publisher=BBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123152554/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6287047.stm |archivedate=23 January 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Activism== A large number of groups and individuals are active in preventing or educating about marine debris. For example, [[5 Gyres]] is an organization aimed at reducing plastics pollution in the oceans, and was one of two organizations that recently researched the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]]. [[Heal the Bay]] is another organization, focusing on protecting [[California]]'s [[Santa Monica Bay]], by sponsoring beach cleanup programs along with other activities. [[Marina DeBris]] is an artist focusing most of her recent work on educating people about beach trash. Interactive sites like Adrift<ref>{{cite web |url=http://adrift.org.au/ |title=Home |website=PlasticAdrift.org |deadurl=no |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=3 February 2015 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> demonstrate where marine plastic is carried, over time, on the worlds ocean currents.
On 11 April 2013 in order to create awareness, artist [[Maria Cristina Finucci]] founded The [[Garbage patch state]] at [[UNESCO]]<ref>{{cite web|date=4 November 2013 |url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/venice/about-this-office/single-view/news/the_garbage_patch_territory_turns_into_a_new_state/#.U71u8fl_u9U |title=The garbage patch territory turns into a new state |website=UNESCO Office in Venice |publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911135638/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/venice/about-this-office/single-view/news/the_garbage_patch_territory_turns_into_a_new_state/#.U71u8fl_u9U |archivedate=11 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> –Paris in front of Director General [[Irina Bokova]]. First of a series of events under the patronage of [[UNESCO]] and of Italian Ministry of the Environment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rivistasitiunesco.it/articolo.php?id_articolo%3D2073 |title=Rifiuti diventano stato, Unesco riconosce 'Garbage Patch' |language=it |trans-title=Waste becomes state, UNESCO recognizes 'Garbage Patch' |accessdate=3 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714144707/http://www.rivistasitiunesco.it/articolo.php?id_articolo=2073 |archivedate=14 July 2014 |website=Siti |df= }}</ref>
Forty-eight plastics manufacturers from 25 countries, are members of the Global Plastic Associations for solutions on Marine Litter, have made the pledge to help prevent marine debris and to encourage recycling.<ref name=":0" />
=== Mitigation === [[File:How_long_until_it's_gone.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|The decomposition times of marine debris]]
Marine debris is a problem created by all of us, not only those in coastal regions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chow|first=Lorraine|date=29 June 2016|title=80% Of Ocean Plastic Comes From Land-Based Sources, New Report Finds.|url=http://www.ecowatch.com/80-of-ocean-plastic-comes-from-land-based-sources-new-report-finds-1891173457.html.|journal=EcoWatch|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Ocean debris can come from as far away as Nebraska. The places that see the most damage are often not the places that produce the pollution. For ocean pollution, much of the trash may come from inland states, where people may never see the ocean and thus may never put any thought into protecting it. The problem continues to grow in tandem with plastics usage and disposal. Steps can be taken to prevent the movement of inland plastics into the oceans.
Plastic debris from inland states come from two main sources: ordinary litter and materials from open dumps and landfills that blow or wash away to inland waterways and wastewater outflows. The refuse finds its way from inland waterways, rivers, streams and lakes to the ocean. Though ocean and coastal area cleanups are important, it is crucial to address plastic waste that originates from inland and landlocked states.<ref>Tibbetts, J. H. (2015). Managing Marine Plastic Pollution. ''Environmental Health Perspectives'', ''123''(4), A90-A93. doi:10.1289/ehp.123-A90</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.oceanicsociety.org/blog/1720/7-ways-to-reduce-ocean-plastic-pollution-todayStrategies|title=7 Ways To Reduce Ocean Plastic Pollution Today|website=www.oceanicsociety.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-29|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330075852/https://www.oceanicsociety.org/blog/1720/7-ways-to-reduce-ocean-plastic-pollution-todayStrategies|archivedate=30 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
At the systems level, there are various ways to reduce the amount of debris entering our waterways: * Improve waste transportation to and from sites by utilizing closed container storage and shipping * Restrict open waste facilities near waterways * Promote the use of [[Refuse-derived fuel]]s. Used plastic with low residual value often do not get recycled and are more likely to leak into the ocean.<ref>''Stemming the tide: Land-based strategies for a plastic-free ocean'' (pp. 1-48, Rep.). (2015). McKinsey Center for Business and Environment.</ref> However, turning these unwanted plastics that would otherwise stay in landfills into refuse-derived fuels allows for further use; they can be used as supplement fuels at power plants * Improve recovery rates for plastic (in 2012, the United States generated 11.46 million tons of plastic waste, of which only 6.7% was recovered<ref>EPA. Municipal Solid Waste Generation, Recycling, and Disposal in the United States: Facts and Figures for 2012 [fact sheet]. Washington, DC:U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (February 2014)</ref> * Adapt [[Extended producer responsibility|Extended Producer Responsibility]] strategies to make producers responsible for product management when products and their packaging become waste; encourage reusable product design to minimize negative impacts on the environment<ref>Nash, Jennifer, and Christopher Bosso. “Extended Producer Responsibility in the United States.” Journal of Industrial Ecology, vol. 17, no. 2, 2013, pp. 175–185., doi:10.1111/j.1530-9290.2012.00572.x.</ref> As consumers, there are things we can do to help reduce the amount of plastic entering our waterways:<ref name=":1" /> [[File:7_Swaps.jpg|thumb|7 simple single-use swaps people can make to save trash.]] * Reduce usage of single-use plastics such as plastic bags, straws, water bottles, utensils and coffee cups by replacing them with reusable products such as reusable bags, metal straws, reusable water bottles, bamboo toothbrushes and reusable coffee cups * Avoid microbeads, which are found in face scrubs, toothpastes and body washes * Participate in a river or lake beach clean up * Support municipality bans and other legislation regulating single-use plastics and plastic waste * Continue to recycle, recycle, recycle Though the awareness of inland ocean conservation debris mitigation seems to be small compared to coastal states, some organizations in the United States are already working to improve this. The Colorado Ocean Coalition was formed in 2011 with the goal of impressing upon inland citizens that they don’t need to see the ocean to care about its health. It has since grown beyond one state and now forms the [https://inlandoceancoalition.org Inland Ocean Coalition], with the mission of promoting knowledge and awareness of how inland states contribute to pollution of the ocean, aiming to shatter the ‘out of sight, out of mind’ mentality that often applies in this region.
“Those who live among mountains, rivers and inland cities have a direct impact on the cycle of life in the ocean,” reads the [https://inlandoceancoalition.org IOCO] website. "The changes we need to make to address the largest threats facing our seas—lowering carbon emissions, reducing trash and pollution, eating sustainable seafood, safeguarding watersheds, promoting marine protected areas (MPAs)—can happen from anywhere in the world.”
This organization has chapters in many inland US states and promotes programs like watershed cleanups, youth-centered education, and decreasing the use of plastic.
